Technical support is going back to the engineers to see if they have any additional ideas and I'm waiting for a response.Update October 30, 2010Technical support and I spent a lot of time on the phone and exchanging emails today. The results of all of this seems to be a suspected faulty bridge. A new one is being sent to me and all concerned hope this will solve the problem. After it is installed I'll update this review; after so many hours of frustration it seems almost too much to hope for.Update October 17, 2010The mystery remains unsolved as of this date; the Logitech level 2 technical support representative has now referred it to their engineering department, it is simply not behaving in a predictable way. I have had contact with the representative even today, Sunday, and we tried yet a few more diagnostic proceedures with no success. The tech said he would have to talk with an engineer again and would get back with me Tuesday. I'll update this review in the future as things develop; needless to say this has made me very curious as to the nature of the problem.Update October 8, 2010I've been in contact with Logitech technical support many times by email and phone and so far no solution has been found to the undetected cameras. I've tried everything I can think of and everything Logitech has been able to suggest so far with no success.I'm working now with a level 2 technician who told me they wanted to start handling this by telephone but that conversation has not taken place yet. As things progress I'll keep this review updated so you will have the benefit of my experience. I have been appreciative of Logitech's help in resolving this challenge; they seem to be hanging in there with me to find out why Alert Commander isn't detecting the cameras.There is more detailed information available in the "Comments" section.Original reviewThe cameras and associated hardware and software came in and I was excited about getting it into operation. Unlike the other reviews I've read to date, I have had a major problem getting the software to detect the cameras. Nothing I did helped so I've contacted Logitech technical support by phone and email and to date even they have not been able to solve the problem.In a recent email they asked me to send them a diagnostic report on the installation; at first I didn't know what they were talking about but after some investigation into the settings menu I found the diagnostic option and ran the program and emailed them the diagnostic report. I did that at the end of last week and when I called Friday I was told the level 2 technician had not had time to review the report and should have some information for me around the first of the following week.The cameras and associated hardware and software all seem of very fine quality they just aren't playing well together yet. To this point the level 1 tech has asked me to make sure the power supplies were plugged in directly to the wall, which they are, and to connect the bridge directly to the router rather than to a switch which was the way I had initially attached it. Even with those alterations the software is not detecting the cameras.I'm personally very intrigued as to why the cameras are not being detected and look forward to getting an opinion from a level 2 tech. As things progress, I'll update this review so if you have a similar problem you'll have the benefit of my experience.

Reviews.Title: it only records motion
Reviews.Author: davep6
Reviews.Content: With increasing suspicious solicitors in my neighborhood I've been wanting a front entry camera.  I spent a lot of time doing research and almost purchased a zmodo DVR type system, or a drop cam.  I went with the logitech after seeing it in action because it seemed easier to set up than a traditional cctv dvr system, with with a brand name like logitech I knew I was going to get a product with directions in broken English.I purchased an indoor master system even though I planned to mount it outside on my porch.  It's under a covered patio and we never have any extreme weather conditions. When the product arrived, it appeared to be factory sealed only the setup DVD and instructions were missing.  I downloaded the software from the logitech website, so that wasn't an issue.  On the first few go-arounds the camera was not recognized.  I thought this may be an issue because although my home isn't that big (approx 1500-1600 sq ft) the plugs I was using were on different circuit breaker panels.  I tried over and over and even plugged the camera and the receiver unit into the same outlet and it still wouldn't work.  It wasn't until I used a paperclip to reset the camera that the software recognized the camera.  I then plugged it into the outlets I originally intended to and it worked just fine.  This sort of led me to believe that the product I purchased could have been refurbished, but maybe I'm wrong.I'm pretty happy with the camera overall.  It covers a good size area and I like that you can configure the software to send you text messages or emails during specific hours of your choosing.  One thing I didn't realize(which i should have) when I purchased this camera was that the recording is based on motion only.  You can always view live video(which was very easy to set up on my Iphone 4s), but actual recording is not continuous. It will record for about 5 seconds every time the camera detects motion.  You can also select the areas you want to monitor for motion so that passing vehicles, etc will not trigger a recording.I still think this is a good option for home surveillance but just remember to reset the camera if the software won't recognize it, and that it will not continuously record until it detects motion.

Reviews.Title: Capable and straightforward
Reviews.Author: Busy Executive
Reviews.Content: I have a vacation home that's vacant a lot, and I've been searching for a video monitoring solution that can keep an eye on it when I'm not there. After trying a few brands, the Logitech seems about the best option short of spending a few thousand dollars on a professional system. To be clear, there are definite limitations, but to me, the results have been worthwhile, especially considering the price.You need a PC (or Mac...there's a recent download on the Logitech site that offers full functionality for Mac OS X) of some sort to act as DVR and central hub for collecting and recording video. This might be a disadvantage if you have no other reason to have a PC, but for me, since I have a PC (actually, a Mac Mini) for a variety of other home automation apps, it's no big deal. I also prefer this approach to cloud-based solutions that require lots of bandwidth to record video to the cloud.The Logitech Alert Commander software installs easily and is generally unobtrusive. As a backup measure, the cameras have 2G of local storage (that you can upgrade to 32G if you like...32G should hold at least a month of data!), so even if there's a problem with the PC connection, the cameras record to their local storage until the PC comes back online. You can also feed live video to Logitech's mobile app or web site, so you're pretty much covered no matter where you want to review video.The camera itself reminds me quite a bit of HAL from the sci-fi classic 2001: A Space Odyssey. About the size of a mobile phone, they are fairly unobtrusive, and Logitech gives you a variety of ways to mount them, from a free-standing dock to suction cups and ball-and-socket brackets.The only connection to the camera is a 48V PoE Ethernet cable, and to me, this is one of the best features of the product. There are many ways to get this type of signal to the camera, so you have lots of flexibility. Certainly, the simplest and most common approach is to use  the Logitech-supplied HomePlug to run Ethernet over your home's electrical wiring. Plugged into outlets near your computer and near your camera, you create an instant network without running cables anywhere.Of course, if you have existing Ethernet, you can use that too - though you'll probably want a PoE injector or a PoE switch since PoE is generally uncommon in the home. There are two advantages of using conventional Ethernet instead of the HomePlug: greater bandwidth (important if you have multiple cameras), and you can make Ethernet fault-tolerant in case of a blackout by connecting your power injector (or switch) to a small UPS...the camera will keep on recording to its internal memory until the power is restored.Some other reviews seem confused about the HomePlug unit and things like extension cords. The problem with home wiring networks is that certain accessories (UPS devices and many surge suppressors) consider the data flowing over your electrical wires to be "noise", and so they filter it out. This might give you purer power, but it also reduces or eliminates the ability for the HomePlug devices to communicate. But, the average simple extension cord has no such filtering capabilities, so it's perfectly fine to connect your HomePlug to a standard extension cord, or to something like a power strip, so long as it does no line filtering.You can also mix-and-match connection options if you want. For instance, if you have several cameras that you want to install near one another, you might use the HomePlug connected to a PoE switch, and then run standard Ethernet to, say, four cameras.To give you an idea, I wanted to put a camera on my outdoor shed to monitor traffic in my driveway. The shed isn't wired into my home's electrical system, so there's no way to use the HomePlug thing. But, I do have a small solar panel on the shed roof, connected to a marine battery and inverter. I was able to use a wireless Ethernet bridge (Netgear) and a power injector to connect an outdoor Logitech 700e camera to my home network, and it works quite well.The other advantage to the Logitech approach is that you're not really locked in to their software. Most security DVR apps (including free, open-source utilities like iSpy) know how to discover and manage PoE cameras like the Alert 7xx series, so if you don't like how Logitech does something, at least you have other options.To me, image quality is very good in bright light, good in dim light and fair in night vision mode. Motion is generally smooth, and there are relatively few effects from excessive image compression. The camera also has a very wide angle view (130 degree - that's like a 12mm ultra-wide angle lens on a 35mm camera) that helps cover large areas with fewer cameras. The night vision mode is effective, and the motion sensing software works well, sending email alerts with an image showing what caused the alert to be triggered. Logitech's mobile app is likewise simple to use and gives you immediate live view access to your camera(s) from anywhere in the world - even if the best you can find is a 3G cellular network connection.One negative was that the camera I bought from Amazon was defective, and it did take a frustrating week of going back and forth with Logitech support before it was replaced. Still, after running some diagnostics to confirm that the camera was indeed defective, they were quick to send me a prepaid UPS shipping label, and I had a replacement in a few days. The replacement has performed perfectly so far.Overall, the Logitech Alert series are flexible, capable cameras that give you lots of options to create a sophisticated monitoring solution for nearly any use. Definitely worth a look.

Reviews.Title: Great features, mediocre reliability
Reviews.Author: Captain-Jec
Reviews.Content: My house was broken in and robbed in Oct'12 so I decided to buy surveillance cameras for monitoring while away. Initially I bought from Costco a set of Uniden cameras but immediately realized that its software was mulfunctioning and resolutoin was too poor to be of any real use, therefore returned them. After consulted with friends, I bought a set of Logitech cameras - one 750e outdoor master, one 750n outdoor add-on, and 2 indoor 700n add-ons. Despite the 2x price tag, I was happy with my choice because of its outstanding designed-in features:a) Its unique architecture to use the same electrical power cord to transmit video signals, and display/store the video clips on a regular PC, as long as it connects to the Internet. This eliminates a seperate box that requires massive cables wired to each camera around the house, making wiring and installation so easy.b) Its crystal clear and color-rish video quality and commendable night vision feature.c) Each camera contains a standard microSD card that stores recorded video before transmits it to the PC. This allows user to expand the local storage as memory cards get cheaper and not to worry about Internet being down.d) Miniature size with a good looking design.e) Cloud based monitoring service provided by Logitech (about $70/year extra) to access video clips from anywhere around the world through Internet, right from an iPhone or Android smartphone. (Although in my view the speed to load videos are a bit slow.)Despite of these great features, I only give it a 3 star because I am disappointed by its poor reliability, even just comparing it to a mediocre electronic device. Here is what happened:A few weeks after initial installation, my outdoor 750e camera started to switch itself to night vision mode randomly during day time. I called customer service, who instructed me to do all sort of things to help them diagnose what was the problem. Remember an outdoor camera is to be installed at a place out of reach from ground. I had to schedule time with their technician, then climbed to the top of my roof multple times to push reset button, unplug memory card, reconnect cable, once at a time, in order to exhust all possibilities to prove that the unit is indeed mulfunctioning beyond repair, before a permision for a replacement unit.Not long after, one of the indoor units simply stopped recording videos. Again I had to go through the same routine to help diagnose the problems before Logitech could issue a replacement.I have now re-installed both failed units with Logitech replacements and pray I won't see more failures anytime soon, but I have a feeling I would.I am an engineer by training working in high tech industry and I understand an on-site fix is much more economical than a replacement. Also I admit that Logitech tech support people are professional and trying their best to help. However a failure rate of 50% within first month only indicates either a poor quality-by-design or poor production quality, not to mention the wasted hours of a consumer who paid premium price only to provide free serve to Logitech for their product problems.

Reviews.Title: Really Nice
Reviews.Author: dogperson
Reviews.Content: I really like this system.  I have been using the Vue wireless cameras, which are very handy because of the ease of placement and absolute independence of wiring (they use batteries), but the picture quality is not great.  It IS with the 700e!  Very clear and vibrant.  I even like the night vision, which just appears as a black/white negative, but still good picture quality.  I like that the cameras are accessible remotely through my IOS devices (with $80 yrly subscription), and controllable as to pan/tilt, focus area, alert settings, etc., all remotely.  Had wanted to get this system before but couldn't because it wasn't Mac friendly.  Now it is.  It was easy to set up and has a very long power to camera cord, which is flat and easily fits through a closed window, so there isn't any place on the exterior of my home that I can't put a camera.  No need to have an outdoor socket.  I also like that you can have up to 6 cameras supported and viewable on the same screen simultaneously.

Reviews.Title: Excellent solution for home surveillance!
Reviews.Author: TheTerrorBeyond
Reviews.Content: This is a very nice security system with some really great possibilities. You can connect up to six cameras to the system and record the video to your computer hard drive for storage. The cameras themselves use micro-SD cards for offline storage as well, so you have options. You can view the live video from the cameras on your local computer with the Logitech Alert Commander software, via the internet on their website, or via the mobile client on your Android, Blackberry, or iPhone.The base system comes with one camera, power supply, network adapter, and Logitech Alert Commander software. The review system came with an additional indoor camera (700i) in order to allow reviewers to set up a system with multiple input points.INSTALLATION:The installation is basically a no-brainer and the system didn't take any time to set up. The cameras communicate via powerline ethernet which runs the data through your existing electrical outlets to your router. This setup allows you to install the cameras anywhere there is an electrical outlet without worrying about running cables through your house. The master system comes with the powerline-to-ethernet connector that you connect to your router, any additional cameras come with powerline adapters that communicate with the master.NOTE: YOU MUST CONNECT THE ADAPTERS DIRECTLY TO A WALL OUTLET. THE ADAPTERS WILL NOT WORK IF PLUGGED INTO A SURGE SUPPRESSOR. The instructions tell you this, but I decided to test it and they were not kidding; it does not work.  These cameras work with POE switches, so you do not need to use the powerline adapters that come with them. I have the cameras connected to a TRENDnet 8-Port 10/100Mbps PoE Switch (4x 10/100, 4x 10/100 PoE) and it works great. I would highly recommend a PoE switch for installation.The Powerline adapters are NOT plenum rated, so Logitech does NOT support installation of the adapters in the attic.SETUP:The setup is pretty straight forward. You connect the cameras to the powerline adapters or a PoE switch and connect to your router. The Logitech Alert Commander software will find the cameras that you connect and you can then name them and they are ready to view.Adding cameras is as simple as plugging the camera cable into the powerline adapter or PoE switch and then using the software to discover the new camera. It is dead simple.CAMERA FIRMWARE:The camera firmware was out of date on the cameras I was sent. Luckily, it is extremely easy to update the firmware. Simply open the Logitech Alert Commander software, select "Settings," select "General," select "Updates," and then click "Update Cameras." You can also update your software from the same location.SOFTWARE:The Logitech Alert Commander software is fairly intuitive, but setting up recording to your computer is not automatic. You must define a path for the audio/video stream or it will not record at all. The path can be set by going to "Settings," selecting "Storage," then "Computer." The "Video location" box will have information entered into it, but it will not work. You MUST define a path for the video by selecting "Browse" and setting up a file path.NIGHT VISION:The night vision seems to work very well. I tested the 750e and 750i in the dark and it was able to pick up pretty good detail. The image is not the best in the world, but it is a lot better than expected and the range is pretty good.VIEWING VIA PHONE OR WEB:This is a great feature and one that I will use often. You simply set up an account when you install the Logitech Alert Commander software on your computer and then use that login information on the phone or the web to view live video from the cameras. This works surprisingly well and I am quite impressed with it. There is also a premium version where you can use Web and Mobile Commander to view recorded video and control your system remotely. I have not looked into the cost of this, but it is a very good feature if you want to have complete remote control of the system.BOTTOM LINE:This is an excellent security system and it will work very well for pretty much anyone. The price is a bit higher than many other systems if you want to install multiple cameras, but it is certainly very high quality.OVERALL RATING: 4.5/5 (reduced 1/2 star for price)HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Reviews.Title: Beware as this camera system is unreliable-50% fail rate for me.
Reviews.Author: J. Holloway
Reviews.Content: This review is revised after 2 years of owning as of Jan 2014. Make sure you set these cameras up in a location you can get to because if you get a bad one you will be fighting with it until tech support agrees to send you a replacement. The problem for me was always the recording on the media card in the camera. Also the system couldn't reliably find and display my camera on screen of my browser. What I learned is if you have to reset it to get it to work you have a problem. Get a replacement. Best Buy stopped selling them. Amazon prices for them are puzzling. Logitech is out of stock on them etc.  I don't know if Logitech is going to discontinue or not. The only things these cameras are missing is 2 way audio. They have one way audio (listening) only.  The other thing I wish it had were better motion video...it's blurry sometimes.  It is an easy system to understand, install and use. I would recommend making sure the system works in your house before you permanently  install it. I purchased the 80.00 a year Logitech alert web access that delivers greater functionalty on the Internet for operating the system from any computer. I do not recommend you spend big money for this system as its long in the tooth and I think they have a high fail rate. Both my cameras are finally working now but its been a difficult time getting to this point.

Reviews.Title: Works great, easy installation
Reviews.Author: Robert Gunia "Sombrero"
Reviews.Content: Every home should have one of these systems to cover basic entry points.  This was an easy installation and it works great.  One might be surprised (We were)by the activities going on just outside the front door.  This system allows you to view at one's convenience clips of activities recorded when motion was detected.  We get email alerts when a designated area such as the back door has activity detected.

Reviews.Title: Has very good range and great features, but performance is shaky - UPDATE
Reviews.Author: M. Hodge "Mark"
Reviews.Content: As a preliminary matter, it should be understood that I had a complicated situation, in which the location where the camera had to be installed was pretty far away from any of *my* electrical sources.  Remember, this is not really a wireless system.  It sends signals through your electrical outlet from the camera to a receiver that you attach to your router, which then can connect wirelessly to your computer that runs the relevant software.  So, if (as in my case) the camera has to be installed in a place in which the closest electrical sources are not on your personal grid (ie. not on my apartment's/condo's electrical bill but rather on that of the management/homeowners association/a neighbor) your computer will, of course, not find the camera.That being said, Logitech's website sells longer ethernet lines for the camera to the small box that broadcasts over the electrical grid.  The 100' one wasn't available and it wouldn't sell me the 40' one at my address (and I couldn't find either on any other website).  So we attempted to run our own ethernet (CAT5e) from the camera to the small box that broadcasts over the electrical grid, which I plugged in right next to the outlet where I plugged the receiver in.  It didn't work.  Moreover, putting a normal ethernet cord into the camera requires you to squeeze it in there and is a nightmare pulling it out because the ethernet cord that comes with the system has a non-standard narrow connector and wire (apparently designed to maintain a degree of weatherproofing via a tight seal with the camera).  In any event, as I said, it simply didn't work.  The computer couldn't see the camera.As an experiment, I bought five 25' industrial extension cords and ran them from the socket in my apartment out the door and all the way to the location where the camera needed to be so that the camera was connected to the broadcaster with the manufacturer's ethernet cord and the broadcaster was connected to my electrical grid via 100' of extension cord.  It worked like a charm.  So we ran an electrical line through the walls to the closest point at which my electrical grid could be found.  So the lesson: (assuming you can't get and test the 40' or 100' non-standard ethernet cord sold by Logitech) you can apparently extend the power line from your electrical grid to the broadcaster, but you can't extend the ethernet line from camera to broadcaster.My original review on performance:  Moving on to performance... I was very excited by the prospect of having the camera notify me via e-mail when the motion detector went off and then having the ability to check what the camera was seeing via the iPhone app.  This is all important because this is not merely a preventative measure but is in response to several instances of someone breaking into cars in my parking lot over the course of the last few weeks.  So, the hope was that the camera would catch him/her in the act, notify me so that I could check the camera via my iPhone from any location, and enable me to call the cops while it was still going on.  However, the motion detection is inconsistent.  Moreover, (and this might be because the camera had to be installed about twenty five-thirty feet from the parking lot, which is itelf probably 80-100' wide) even when someone is at the closest point in the parking lot, I could not make out a face even with the image zoomed in 100%.  In addition, regardless of the quality of my internet access/bandwidth (ie. hardwired broadband at home and 5 bar 3G and 5 bar Wifi), I can only see images via the iPhone app periodically, such that starting and stopping the app five times in a row *might* connect once.  This was the case even when I was testing the camera with no extension cords, plugged into the wall socket right next to the receiver (again hardwired broadband and 5 bar Wifi/5 bar 3G to my iPhone).UPDATE:Ultimately, I realized that the main reason that my iPhone app could only periodically see my cameras was because the Alert website itself could only periodically see my cameras.  The iPhone app simply connects to Logitech's Alert website, so if the website doesn't have it, the iPhone app won't have it.  Logitech support had me test my internet connection, which was strong (5 Mbps Download / 1 Mbps Upload).  After fiddling with the camera, the receiver, the plugs, the program, the website, and plenty of time on the phone with Logitech support trying to figure out why their website could only periodically get a signal from my computer, I finally gave up on using their Alert website and their iPhone app in favor of LogMeIn (a free remote-access program/service).  I already had a LogMeIn account to connect to my office computer from home and away.  It turns out there is an iPhone app for LogMeIn as well (free).  I downloaded and installed LogMeIn on the computer that hosts my security cameras, connecting to the website to add it as a computer along with my office computer, installed the LogMeIn iPhone app, logged into LogMeIn, selected the computer that hosts my security cameras and there was my (home) computer screen on my iPhone, complete with the security camera images in real time.  Even better, I could adjust everything from my iPhone, including turning the motion detection alerts off and on, etc.  All that being said, it looks like Alert is getting ready to replace their existing cell phone apps in the immediate future with new programs (rather than updates).  I don't know if that will be any better, but I suspect that if the website cannot consistently see your security camera image, no iphone app reliant upon that website will do so either.I purchased a Logitech Add On Camera to cover the other side of the parking lot and installation was a snap.  Plugged the Logitech ethernet cord in the power adapter on one side and into the camera itself on the other, plugged the power adapter into the wall, and told the computer running the Alert system to search for a second camera... and there it was.I'm still reliant on the Alert program on my home computer to deal with e-mail/text message alerts when the motion detector goes off, and the option to send a "snap shot" to my cell phone doesn't actually send an image, just a text message that tells you to look at the attached image (which isn't there).At this point, with the exception of getting an answer to the "snap shot" issue, I feel that I just need to tweak the sensitivity on my motion detection (which is controlled in the program very easily) to have things just as I imagined they would be.  Ultimately, with the substitution of LogMeIn, this system works wonderfully.  In as much as there appears to be a free version of LogMeIn that provides these functions (including cell phone access), this is certainly no big burden and a very easy fix.  With that in mind, I am increasing my rating to four stars.  If it wasn't necessary to use free outside software to get all the remote access functions to work properly on my system, I would give it five stars.

Reviews.Title: Nice quality video and pictures. Easy setup.
Reviews.Author: medhchang
Reviews.Content: I bought this and an add-on 700e outdoor camera. Both were easy to mount with the provided hardware. The kit even comes with screwable guides to tuck the ethernet cable to the power supply. Having a drill would be handy to pre-drill the screw holes for mounting the camera.After downloading the software via Logitech's website I was able to update the firmware on my two cameras and was up and running in minutes. Video quality is excellent. It is easy to setup where to store your videos and how aggressive you want to record the areas being monitored. You can also adjust the field-of-view of each camera to avoid having to manually move the camera.The downsides to the system is Logitech's $80/year fee if you want to use their web-based system to view recorded videos or to adjust the camera settings. You are supposed to install the desktop software only to one computer. The free version of the web-based software lets you view live feeds of all your cameras. That's it. Price seems steep to me considering the price premium of these cameras compared to competitors.Still the ease of setup and quality of the video counts for alot.If your interested in buying the cameras I would check Logitech's website as they have changing promo offers. I was able to pick up an outdoor master camera and 3 add-ons for $760. I ended up returning the cameras I bought from Amazon after I was declined a price match.Edit: one major problem is that if there is a temporary power loss (i.e. the lights turn on/off for less than 5 seconds) the cameras will lose contact with your computer. The only solution I have found is to reset the cameras by unplugging them from the wall for a minute, then replugging them back in. This is a major problem if you intend to use these cameras in a remote location that you do not regularly visit. Took a star off for this issue until Logitech fixes it.

Reviews.Title: Good but Has Some Issues
Reviews.Author: Scott in SC
Reviews.Content: Overall I like the system.  The camera is very sturdy.  The mount is not as well built as the camera.  I tested the camera indoors prior to mounting and found that it got quite warm.  I am not sure if it actually has a heating element in it or not.  The indoor camera did not get hot.I initially could not connect with any camera.  I looked through the online documentation which was useless.  I eventually found that my router (D-link DIR 655) had a setting for multimedia data which was turned off.  After changing that I had no problems finding the cameras during testing.  I would have thought the documentation for the camera would have something about checking router settings as D-Link is a pretty common router brand.The major frustration I had was with the home plug data transfer.  I plugged the camera in the outlet I was using for it's final installation.  I was able to get the camera to connect.  However after I went and mounted everything permanently the system would only connect sporadically.  It turns out the outlet I used was at the end to the circuit and the connection was very weak when it did connect.  You can check the signal strength which I did not do prior to permanent mounting.  I eventually did find another outlet that gave a better signal but I had to add a 25 ft ethernet cable to get to it.  Since then the system works very reliably.  I have an indoor and outdoor camera and plan to add another outdoor camera soon.The motion detection works well.  The clarity of the image is not bad but you can't recognize faces at 50ft from the camera.  The night vision works well but I wish the emitters were not visibly red.  It's very obvious.  I have seen other emitters that are not visible at night so I know it can be done.  The LED signal indicators can be turned off through the software.I really like the software but it has quirks too.  You can't maximize the program window and see all camera views together.  You only get a large image of one camera not the collage of all cameras you see in the smaller window.  Also you can't see any live images when remote connecting to the computer.  You can't see recorded video either unless you pull up the video files directly.  The web connect works well for live images but you can't get recorded video unless you pay the annual fee.Overall I would buy again but you better be prepared for some effort to get it all started.

Reviews.Title: Good plug 'n play security camera system
Reviews.Author: Scott "IT Pro & Hardware Guru"
Reviews.Content: This is a good consumer grade security camera system that anybody can install and get above average video/images with great iphone/ipad and software integration.The video quality isn't quite real HD, and you don't have a real optical zoom to help make out any details. However it is a much higher resolution that competing cameras in this price range and not having any moving parts or motors means one less thing to break over time, especially in bad weather.The only major complaint I have with these units is the poor motion detection, and that the video quality still needs to higher to better make out individuals at a distance.Also while you can pay ($80/yr) for the online "Alert" internet service, your cameras do NOT automatically upload to the internet, when you check videos, only then does your camera or remote PC and web browser request the video which is then loaded from your cameras memory card and transmitted to your device.Still, unless something better comes along or you're lucky enough to have several thousand dollars to spend on commercial grade HD security cameras this is likely your best bet today.Update: I've had the 700e operating outdoors in heavy snow and rain last winter and it has run perfect without any issues common to outdoor security cameras such as condensation/fogging. The night vision has done fairly well too, a single Par light off to the side of the house or any other ambient lighting nearby provides plenty of light for the unit to illuminate my driveway fully.

Reviews.Title: Very good, but not perfect.
Reviews.Author: EJL
Reviews.Content: I have two of these cameras (and one indoor camera) set up in my house.  I've also had a third outdoor camera that had to be returned for being defective.  When these cameras work, they are great, however the internal SD card writer seems to fail very often.  Out of three outdoor cameras, two have failed SD cards.  I returned the one (which also had overheating and video failure issues), but the other is already mounted high on my home.  The camera will not put footage on your computer using the stock software with a failed SD card. I have tried replacing the SD card and the same issues crop up, leading me to believe its the units themselves.  My solution is to use Blue Iris video recording software.  This takes the live stream and records it on my server's hard drive.The video quality from these cameras is very good.  The motion sensitivity is not.  It may pick up any movement trees and squirrels make in my yard, but it missed the UPS delivery of an Amazon package.  One recording the package is not there, the next a squirrel is looking at my package.I'd recommend these cameras for use if you have the ability to use a server and alternate software.  They would do a great job if you record all the time on them, but I would not trust the motion detection on these, or any other camera.  When these cameras work, they are good, but in my small sample size I've had problems.

Reviews.Title: A lot of features for the price
Reviews.Author: Amy from Houston
Reviews.Content: Bought the 750 master system with outdoor camera and then added a second outdoor camera within 7 days. The very first time I took it out of the box and plugged it in the video image came up immediately BUT...then it vanished and I could not get the camera recognized again. Ended up installing the Commander software on a different laptop in the house and got it working. Probable total time from the first attempt to when it was working was 90 minutes. Camera does not seem to interact well with certain firewall software.One of our cameras is installed under the roof eave of our two story home and is probably 25-30 feet off the ground. It points at the front yard, our driveway, the street and catches neighbors' homes across the street. Image quality at that distance during the day is decent but not fantastic. You could identify a make, model and color of car but definitely can not make out a license plate...its just too far. Night vision at this distance isn't great.The other camera is installed above our garage and looks down our driveway where we park our vehicles. It points at things much closer up than the other camera and the images are much clearer and higher quality.You can use the software to identify motion zones: if something enters a predefined motion zone the camera records what it sees. The camera does an okay job of confining its recording to only movement within the zones, but tends to err on the side of recording versus not recording, which is probably a good thing.I love being able to monitor the cameras over the Internet. There is no cost for this, just go the the URL, enter your UN and PW and you can view the live feed.Between the master system and the add-on camera I paid about $600. I feel I got good value for the money and after 2 weeks of constant use I am satisfied with the product.

Reviews.Title: An Awesome Home System
Reviews.Author: Brett
Reviews.Content: I've had this running for two weeks now. I have to admit, I like this system.I'm an IT person and we have a sophisticated DVR system where I work (Expensive too). The video quality of the Logitech is much better. Set up was totally a no brainer.Being able to view my cameras at home from work is a plus.Enjoy this if you purchase it. I recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Hardware, Lousy Software
Reviews.Author: rmcalist
Reviews.Content: Most folks reviews are sufficient in telling about this product.  I wanted to talk about the software in my buyer beware segment!  While I loved how easy the camera's were to set up, and that they were PoE ready, I was disappointed that I had to set them up on a Windows PC.  I am a Mac OSX users, so I had to set it up on my roommates PC.  This was not very convenient, and why doesn't Logitech have software for Mac?One nice thing is that once setup, you don't have to do a whole lot with the Computer.  You can VLC into the camera's as they support RTSP, and you can use third party software to control them (Think Blue Iris Software).  They even have iPhone and iPad app's that you can view the live streams from, pretty cool right?  Nope..  Here's why.You have to pay, $80 a year top view video playback on your mobile device and on the web.  Come On Logitech! I just dropped $600 on your HW, and you can't even give me remote video playback software for free?  I could understand a one time price of $80 or $100, but they want a subscription out of you.  Very disappointed with this, BOOO on you Logitech.So, one of my co-workers turned me onto Blue Iris Software, which gives you remove video playback for these, and other camera's, for $50.  Lifetime.  Its a much better deal.  The one bummer with the software, is again, Windows only.Overall, Camera's are great, Software sucks.Pros:- Nice design, waterproof- Easy setup and Install- Great video quality (720p)- Price is very good, for what you getCons:- Poor Software for video playback- Pay subscription for above features- Windows ONLY software

Reviews.Title: Super Product
Reviews.Author: Rick no W
Reviews.Content: Received the product last night and had it installed and up and running in one hour--not bad for someone who is not too handy. The software download was flawless (vista; I also have it streaming to my blackberry...way too cool. The optics are decent and the field of vision is excellent, in my opinion. All in all, I am totally happy with this purchase and would highly recommend it to anyone as a camera security system that is well designed and solidly built. Five Stars!

Reviews.Title: Very satisfied, easy to setup
Reviews.Author: E. Clarke
Reviews.Content: Nothing but positive things to say so far. It took about 30 minutes to setup outside and about 10 minutes for the software. Everything was VERY easy, and it was working right away. Picture quality is great, haven't tested the audio yet. Will probably be getting some additional cameras to go with the system.

Reviews.Title: Not the Secure Feeling I Was Hoping For
Reviews.Author: crtnyhdvs
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Logitech Alert 750e Outdoor Master System in March after my property had been vandalized. The set up was not as easy as some reviews make it seem. I am not a tech person, but I'm also not an idiot. I downloaded the software carefully following the instruction guide, located dedicated outlets, properly positioned the network adapter and power supply, and went through the business of installing the wall mount on my front porch. After all that, the software couldn't "locate" the camera despite numerous attempts. I fiddled with the router and worked backwards through the instructions to troubleshoot the disconnect only to have to call customer support. After walking me in and out of my front door between the camera and my office desktop, the rep finally suggested that I reset the camera with a paper clip. Fine. The camera and software were communicating at last. I just wish he had suggested that in the first place. That only took about two hours; not quite how I would describe "easy set-up." I also would have appreciated it if Logitech were a bit more specific about necessary tools for installation, i.e. what size drill bit to use would have been helpful instead of trial and error. In addition, an extra pair of hands would've been clutch when I was trying to mount the camera on the wall.Aside from the less-than-stellar set-up experience, I am none too thrilled that the power supply is connected to an outdoor outlet which also happens to be a GFI outlet. This did not present any problems in the first month, but when I recently attempted to run Alert Commander on my computer to view the previous night's recordings, it shut the camera down. When I called customer support, I was told the system doesn't like GFI outlets. I can't say that I know of anyone who doesn't have outdoor GFI outlets for code/safety reasons. It was recommended that I try an extension cord to see if that will rectify the problem. I don't have an extension cord in the house that isn't already in use and the thought of running a cord through a front window or door to another outlet is just not an acceptable solution especially given what I paid for the system. It looks like my only option will be to drill a hole through the exterior wall to run the cable from the porch into a living room outlet which I'm sure is easier said than done. As it stands now, the camera is running without benefit of the software, text alerts, or much else to recommend it. And I am praying that it is actually recording to the SD card otherwise the thing is all but useless to me until I can find a more agreeable resolution to the problem. I'm also not thrilled about the business of climbing up on a ladder to retrieve the SD card which essentially announces to the neighbors and everyone else, "Here's the camera. Come help yourself to it and the memory card! Just make sure you unplug it first."On one last note, the night vision proved to be pretty poor, and in some instances, completely failed to detect and record any activity come nightfall which, of course, is when most of the shenanigans occur in my neighborhood.All in all, it seems ridiculous that Logitech would make a GFI-incompatible outdoor camera which they recommend plugging into an outdoor outlet (as pictured in the instructions) many of which are GFI as required by electrical code. Logitech Alert 750e Outdoor Master System has brought me little to no peace of mind since installing it. I would recommend that anyone considering the system take a long, hard look at the product and its system requirements (dedicated, non-GFI outlets) to determine if it will in fact address their own home security needs or be more of a headache than its actually worth.

Reviews.Title: Works well for me, would like Mac version
Reviews.Author: Robert C. Boyer
Reviews.Content: I bought the master system and installed the external camera about 20' above my driveway.  Installation was incredibly easy, and the camera worked well right away.  It was simple for me to drill a hole through the house at an inconspicuous location and run the flat ethernet cable to the camera, so I didn't need to mount the power supply outdoors.  Since it seemed to work well, I added an indoor camera in another area of the house, and it has also worked flawlessly.The motion detection works well, and I'm receiving email alerts with snapshots when deliveries are made or whenever there's some activity on the driveway.  I live in a rural area so I'm looking forward to catching some pictures of the animals that roam over our lot.Since our internet ISP forces a double-NAT situation, we are unable to set up an externally-accessible web server at our house, so the technique Logitech uses here of pushing updates to their server (when motion is detected) is great for us.  The $79 yearly fee doesn't seem excessive considering that you don't have to constantly have a server running at your house as other systems require.I had some initial trouble with the iPhone app being unable to download recorded clips, but it seems to have "fixed itself" (maybe a problem on the server has been addressed?) and now works every time.  An iPad app would be great, I hope Logitech is working on that...in the mean time you can run the iPhone app on the iPad in "2x" mode.The Logitech forum for this product is useful and seems to be monitored by Logitech personnel.  I get the impression that they're actively developing the software and that updates are frequent, which is a good sign.All in all I'm very happy with the system and plan on getting more cameras.  My only gripe is the lack of a Mac application, hence 4 starts instead of 5.

Reviews.Title: Quite Impressed
Reviews.Author: Brian M. Edwards
Reviews.Content: This system is quite a surprise! It does a lot, is solid,  well built and meant to last. I had to read the installation sheet twice but after that it really was very easy to set up. The system has a box that plugs into your router and into your power supply, the cameras are then plugged into your power supply and the signals travel through your house wiring to the receiving box plugged into the router. I can now watch live video of my front yard and also my living room (I also have an interior camera) which I could also use to monitor if I so wanted to. The daytime video is close to HD quality, night vision is monochrome and acceptable.Some of the great features this system has is that the cameras each some with a  2 gig mini SD card pre-installed that record video whenever the camera detects motion. This video can be played back anytime (though the card will erase data as it becomes full and needs more space)But wait...there's more, if you create an account on the Logitech web-site, you can monitor your cameras from anywhere with  internet service. It comes with "apps" for some cellphones though it does not work on mine but it is possible to also monitor video right on your phone whenever you want, it can even send you alters whenever motion is detected!You can also pan the cameras a little to view areas just out of the cameras reach which is pretty neat.This system is not cheap, but is meant to last, a rarity in today's world full of cheaply made consumer products!I will be adding another exterior camera to cover my back yard though it can accommodate up to an impressive 6 cameras total!If you need a quality set of video cameras that you wish to install yourself, with all the described features, this would be a good bet! I really cannot think of any negatives... what nice deal!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed and frustrated
Reviews.Author: B. Bailey
Reviews.Content: Disappointed and frustrated in this Logitech item - even though we've had success with many of their other products. I set this camera/software up in 15 minutes in a temporary test location before installing permanently. It worked fairly well, except for the night vision, but I was willing to live with this short-coming. After installing "by the book" permanently, this system could not locate the camera. Even though all components in this very simple configuration were installed correctly, and LED's indicated that all was well, tech support was not able to provide a solution outside of trying a longer Ethernet cable (???!!!) and resetting, plugging, unplugging and re-plugging all connections. After investing my Saturday morning drilling, installing, and fruitless troubleshooting - I'm packing it up to return to good old reliable Amazon.

Reviews.Title: A very expensive hassle
Reviews.Author: zebrair
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in an effort to begin setting up a surveillance system at my home. There were two goals: observe my dog while I was at work & monitor my front porch, as I had been experiencing package thefts. I researched systems and was torn between this one and Dropcam. This system was much more expensive, but offered more options in terms of saving video, as well as better picture quality, so I made the leap. After going through two systems, I returned the last one for a full refund.The biggest problem was spotty connectivity. I never did figure out the cause of this. I had a brand new wireless router, high-speed broadband internet, and yet, even when the camera and adapters were in the same room, I could not get them to connect consistently. When I did get the system running, I was scared to unplug the camera to change its location because I was afraid it would not connect again.The second problem, and the *likely* cause of the connectivity issues, was with the adapters. The system comes with two huge network adapters that communicate with each other and connect your camera to the internet and to your local computer. I went through two of these. One overheated and stopped working after less than two days of use. The other did not work right out of the box. On my third attempt, the adapters functioned, but the above-noted connectivity issues arose again, which led to my decision to withdraw the $300 investment and return the entire system.Other issues: Logitech charges for cloud/online access/live streaming of the video through smart devices or remote locations. However, it is free to have the video live stream to your local PC. To overcome this issue, I installed a desktop access software called Teamviewer. It worked great, as Teamviewer even has an iPhone app that allowed me to watch my dog anytime, from anywhere. I installed the program on my home computer, my work computer, and my iPhone and I was able to monitor the dogs from anywhere. Logitech's app was not reliable and gave only blurry images. However, as well as this all worked, it was a lot of effort and very time-consuming to get it all set up. I am pretty tech-savvy, so I was able to get things to work, but I can't imagine the outcome if my mother had been the one trying to set this all up. It never would have happened. The other drawback to this is that my local PC had to be on ALL THE TIME. The impact on my electricity bill was notable, though less than the cost of Logitech's cloud service. Nonetheless, once all costs were combined and the time investment was added in, this system just wasn't worth it.The picture quality was OK, not great. It was difficult to find a proper angle for the camera, especially when hanging on the inside of a window to monitor my porch. All in all, just not worth the very high price for so much hassle and very little return.

Reviews.Title: Logitech 961-000391 Alert 750 Indoor Security Master System and add on
Reviews.Author: Susan Simon
Reviews.Content: Did not work one camera worked other did not sent it back and was not pleased the way I was treated!!On the phone,

Reviews.Title: Incredible product!
Reviews.Author: Jack Funda
Reviews.Content: I have four of these cameras mounted around our primary home.  They have been up and running for about a year and a half and going strong!  I truly did not expect the system to be this reliable and this robust. I installed them as a bit of a novelty, but they have now become a real security system.I looked at all sorts of solutions and settled on the Logitech package because of the HD camera resolution, solid night vision, option to record sound, single (Ethernet) output cable, local (camera-mounted) recording storage, and no DVR box.  I wanted the system to make the cameras available on my home network and let my Mac take it from there.It works like a charm.  The Commander software works well and is simple enough to use.  The remote access to the cameras  (via iPad, for example) is extra cool.  You can watch live video from your cameras from anywhere in the world - all you need is an Internet connection.Setup requires some work (assuming you want your cabling to be neat and tucked out of sight) but the documentation is clear and complete.  Assuming you plug the cameras into clean, direct-line electric circuits (no power strips, etc), chances are you will get a decent signal and all will be well.I have been very impressed with the build quality of the cameras.  They are sophisticated little special-purpose computers, and I have been impressed that they have withstood the elements for a year and a half now, running 24/7 with no trouble at all.What the documentation is not clear about - and what I have come to appreciate as the system's best feature - is that these cameras are fully PoE (power over Ethernet) compatible.  What this means is that - should the powerline-based HomePlug connection ever flake out (as mine did recently for reasons unknown), you can connect the cameras directly to your (PoE capable) router!This was not obvious to me during the initial install and I installed all of the cameras using the included HomePlug adapters (which inject the cameras' signals onto the powerline network of the house) and the included adapter which plucks the video signals from the powerline and feeds them to your router.  This seemed to work OK for several months (with some occasional hiccups), but I noticed that the diagnostics suggested the signal strength for some of the cameras was weak.  When two of the cameras suddenly went dark on me recently, I looked into this again and found that there was another (better) way to connect the cameras.What you will need is either a PoE capable Ethernet switch or router (most basic switches/routers are not) or an inexpensive mid span PoE injector for each camera.  This will provide power to the camera and allow you to connect the Ethernet connection coming from the camera directly into a standard router/switch.  Voila!  The beauty of this setup is that your connection bandwidth will be rock solid.  No more dropouts if the electrical circuit gets overloaded.In short, I could not be happier with this system.  The cameras are exceptionally well built and offer multiple connectivity options.  My only suggestion to Logitech would be to make the versatility of the connectivity options more obvious to the consumers.  This is a major feature and a key competitive differentiator, yet nowhere to be found in the documentation.Great product!

Reviews.Title: Great camera, great software!
Reviews.Author: P. L. Dwyer "irishmoonfrog"
Reviews.Content: I have four of these in my office. They are super easy to install. Just don't plug into a surge strip. A plain extension cord is ok.  The hardware for wall mounting is very easy to use, but the little countertop stand is just fine too.  I have had three of them for four years now. The SD cards wear out after about 2 years and have to be replaced.  One of the four cameras just stopped recording (it still captured images and sent them to the server, but it didn't record them), so I just recently replaced it with this one that I am reviewing.The software is superb.  Setting your own motion detection zones is easy.  It never fails to find the cameras, displays them just as you want, and makes it really easy to playback recordings.  I've used the remote viewing app for both Android and iPhone, and both work flawlessly.The only minuses are: 1. motion detection is based on changes in the image, so the one in our reception area is affected by car headlights sweeping the room at night.  2. There is no way to remove a camera from the program if the camera is not connected. So if a camera were destroyed, you'd have to uninstall and reinstall the whole program in order to get rid of it. I assume that would work; I discovered this when replacing the one that had stopped recording, and I just re-connected it, removed it from the feed, and disconnected it again.

Reviews.Title: Night vision so-so because of insects
Reviews.Author: So Cal Landlord
Reviews.Content: I have used four of these for over a year, and just added an indoor version (700i) to replace a lesser camera in my barn owl box. At night so many insects are attracted to the light on the 700e cameras that many video clips of insect activity are recorded, so I have turned off night vision. Even though they are advertised as outdoor, one of mine leaked water to the inside while under warranty and was replaced free. Since then I have enclosed all of my outdoor cameras in bird houses that I made to hide and protect them, and I have had no more problems with water getting inside. The "live" display on the computer screen is not truly "live" all of the time. Nevertheless I am generally happy with my setup, and I especially like that they record color video clips when motion is detected (as long as they have AC power), which are automatically stored for several months on my computer hard drive when my computer and network come up again. Two of my 700e units use Ethernet over power line for part of the 900 foot distance to my computer and two use separately purchased 48 volt power over Ethernet injectors, all with satisfactory results.

Reviews.Title: Some good, some bad
Reviews.Author: djs
Reviews.Content: Logitech QC is horrible. The first one was DOA. The camera can never be able to power on. The second one works. This camera uses TI DaVinci DM365 DSP, low resolution CMOS sensor, IR cut and illuminator. DM365 is a very sophisticated DSP and can do a lot of complicated duties. But Logitech blocked many of the services. If you have 48V POE injector (you can get it at digikey for $20), you do not need to buy a kit. A stand alone camera (Alert 700n) will be sufficient for all the tasks.Good:1) Relative simple setup procedure.2) Wide angle lens is especially useful for small area surveillance3) Logitech provide web server to provide alert/remote view.Bad:1) Shutter speed is too low. Most of time I received blur images.2) Significant delay (2-3 sec in average). If you move fast enough, you can pick up something without sending a warning.3) Not effective to detect small/slow object4) Horrible image quality at room light, low lightRecommend to use in:1) small room surveillance. If you only need monitor door,  buy one with 70 degree view angle (they are cheaper)2) monitoring places with controlled access -- you know who will be there. If you don't know who will come, Alert will not help you because it mainly produces blur images.Things need to be improved by Logitech:1) Not just alert.logitech.com, we need user defined host name2) Increase shutter speed, we are already fad up with blur images

Reviews.Title: Horrible excuse for outdoor camera
Reviews.Author: Juan lassiter
Reviews.Content: Bought two of these cameras back in February of this year to deter suspicious activity on my property. They both were unusable in about three months because of rainwater getting behind the lens and fogging  them up. I called Logitek at this point and they told me that there was nothing they could do because that cameras are were water resistant not waterproof. My question is how can you advertise a camera for outdoors use and it not be waterproof did they assume that it wasn't going to rain when designing the camera. For the price these cameras are garbage I hope this prevent someone else from making a $600 mistake.

Reviews.Title: My camera broke, I sent it to Logitech, and they closed my issue without sending the replacement.
Reviews.Author: Bria Thompson
Reviews.Content: I am disappointed. I bought the Alert camera system and installed it and my outdoor camera only worked for a month. It was too late to return through Amazon so I contacted Logitech's warranty department. I was told I would be eligible for a replacement and that a shipping label would come to my email in 24-48 hours. None came.I had to then contact support (again) where they told me they couldn't generate a label without my address, which no one asked me for (or notified me they did not have). Finally I get my label and I return my camera.I am then notified it has been received and that I should be getting notification of my replacement camera's shipping info. Nothing comes. A few days later I get an email that my issue is closed. Nice.It's been well over a month now that I've not had a working camera - not a very effective security system with a non functional and now a non-existent camera. I contacted support today concerned that my issue has been closed and yet here I am without my broken camera or any news of receiving a replacement. I am now told the cameras are backordered and I will not receive one for several more weeks. I was only told this because I contacted Logitech myself, no updates were given to me without my calls to support.I guess Logitech expects their customers who trust in their ability to provide security (through an expensive camera system) to just wait patiently for their replacements for weeks on end. In the meantime I am using up my valuable warranty period (clearly I've lost confidence in the ability of the cameras to last and work properly for a long period of time) with no camera at all.If you buy this, I hope yours works more than a month. And if you have to replace it via warranty - I hope you actually get a camera back!

Reviews.Title: questionable quality control
Reviews.Author: Vinny
Reviews.Content: I received this system only to find that the camera was defective. Amazon was great handling the exchange and the new camera works well. I subsequently purchased another camera from another dealer through amazon and this camera was also defective. I did receive a refund yet I question the manufacturer's quality control as I received only one out of three camera's that worked. I'm now reluctant to purchase another to expand my system

Reviews.Title: Super easy to set up and has been flawless
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera system to keep an eye on my vacation property. Before I found the Logitech system I tried a pair of foscam cameras. Never again! I'm not an IT professional but I know how to get around my network. I spent countless hours trying to get those cameras to work remotely with no success. I have no idea how that could be the #1 rated camera on Amazon other than the pile of bogus reviews upping their rating.That's when I began to look for an easier to set up option. The Logitech Alert system is just that. Within minutes I had the camera up and running. I can't imagine how it could be any easier. I'm so impressed I'm ordering two more. I went with indoor cameras to watch the front and back of my home. I did that partly for simplicity and the fact that I didn't want someone to show up with a ladder and help themselves to my camera. As others have mention the night vision is useless if you have the camera looking through glass as the IR lights reflect back at the lens and wash the picture out.The camera has a fixed lense so you can't pan, tilt or zoom. The good news is the fixed lense is quite good. With the Web Commander ($80/yr), or from the computer you set the camera(s) up on, you can use the zoom button to focus in on one area which brings the image closer but I wouldn't call it a true zoom.I use the mobile apps for my ipad and iphone. They have worked perfectly with no problems. I find the mobile apps more user friendly than the Web Commander for reviewing past recorded clips and a snapshot of the image is shown.To date the camera has been working flawlessly for a month. I opted for the $80/year subscription so I could remotely view the video. You can view the camera for free but you have no control remotely if you wanted to view the recorded video or change the settings. I was concerned that having the camera send video back to the Logitech server for storage would adversely impact my internet usage at the vacation home. Surprisingly the amount of data has been negligible. I'm allotted 100 GB per month and in the last month I have used less than .5 GB.Coming from my frustrating foscam experience I could only go up and the Logitech Alert system did not disappoint me. It does exactly what it claims to do without messing around with router settings etc.  Granted it's only been a month but the product has performed perfectly and is worthy of 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Flawless
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: Flawless set up on a MacBook Pro running Mountain Lion, iphone 5, ipad3 and ipad mini.Zero problems or complaints. My house has is 85 years old and has some older wiring and I was expecting some problems but everything works perfectly. Best set up is Mac on all the time to log videos but not necessary. It will upload when you turn it on anyway but I like not having a delay while it loads to my hard drive, chose not to use Dropbox for my storage but that's an option. The Mac is on wifi only and I average 9mbps speed, very minimal lag or load to watch live view on the iPads via wifi and I have att LTE for the iPhone.

Reviews.Title: Good camera but poor service
Reviews.Author: Robert Beeman
Reviews.Content: I've actually had this camera since 2011, so I have quite a bit of experience with it. The camera itself is very high quality. I have had it outdoors for almost two years now, and it has taken the weather like a champ. It has never failed me. That said, I have mixed emotions about this product. My main complaints are regarding Logitech's software and service. Several of its remote features require an $80/year "premium" service fee, which I think is ridiculous. They should be standard. They charge because they proxy all viewing traffic through their servers. This makes the camera extremely easy to set up, but it also constantly causes delays when viewing due to server/bandwidth congestion. When viewing from a mobile device, you will be staring at a "loading video" message more often than actually viewing the camera footage. All of this is fixed by dropping Logitech's software and using Blue Iris instead. I recently switched, and I am very pleased.What I like:* Small body attracts little attention. People have rarely even noticed that it existed.* Weather proof body* Image is bright and clear, but not "HD." It is difficult to read a license plate on a parked car. It is not possible at all if the car is moving.* Very easy to set up due to power line communication provided by the Master System* Logitech's servers facilitate locating and connecting to the cameras from mobile devices. This is much more user friendly than having to identify your external IP address and open proper firewall ports.* Night vision works well.What I don't like:* Lack of physical Pan/Tilt/Zoom. The digital PTZ degrades the image quality.* When viewing your camera remotely, Logitech restricts you to 3 minutes (10 minutes if you pay for "premium") at a time before it disconnects you.* Logitech's servers and/or bandwidth seem to be overly burdened. It takes a long time to connect to the feed and then is has to keep "loading video" over and over.* While the lens is wide screen, the video resolution is not. So it creates some distortion of the image.* It only produces 15 fps max.* Last January, Logitech announced they will be selling their digital video security divisions (http://www.engadget.com/2013/01/23/logitech-q3-earnings-selling-harmony-remotes/), so I'm not sure what that means for the product's future.If you have a PoE (power over ethernet) switch, or PoE injector, within range of the 50ft cable that comes with the camera, you can save yourself some money and buy the camera by itself without the Master System.Like I said before, almost all of the issues that I have with this camera are resolved with the Blue Iris software Foscam Blue Iris Professional - Supports Many IP Camera Brands Including Foscam and Agasio, Zone Motion Detection, H.264 Compression Recording, E-mail And SMS Text Messaging Alerts! for a one time cost. It is more difficult to set up, and it isn't as aesthetically pleasing, but it is much more versatile and functional.

Reviews.Title: bad quality
Reviews.Author: Kunjie
Reviews.Content: Got it, Setup is easy. 1). Running for about 4 hours then one of the camera dead. Call the CS the next day, found out that the Camera Adapter need been replaced. Still waiting for it. 2). After running for 5 days, the Network  Adapter dead, too. CS is going to send me a new one. Still waiting for it.If any of the parts show any problem, I'll return it for sure...Yes, nice and clear video...(only)update 5/30/13: Got the Camera Adapter after 6 days. Unsure if it is working since the Network Adapter still not arrive yet...

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera So Far!
Reviews.Author: John M
Reviews.Content: I've had the Logitech Alert 750e Outdoor Master Security System with Night Vision for 3 weeks, and so far it has been an awesome camera and system.I've tried other cameras (2 $100 pan/tilt/zoom and 1 $600 hidden alarm clock) that were garbage, and I had to return.The quality and packaging is very good, and setup was extremely easy.  I love the fact that the video is transmitted through my existing house wiring.I don't know if the video being recorded is really high def, but it along with the night vision is pretty good compared to what I've used.  *Note: this camera has just 2 IR lights and they are visible at night.I haven't found any motion sensor that works 100% of the time, and this camera is no exception.  However I believe it's working about 99% of the time.  When motion is detected the camera records about 3 seconds prior to the motion and about 3 seconds after.  At a setting of 30 (0-100), birds will trigger the motion sensor.I haven't tried to view live video remotely yet, but the camera has emailed me snapshots based on motion.  I like what I see.My complaints:The cameras can't be turned on and off with the software or a switch (you have to unplug).  The default file names are about 15 plus random characters.  The files are broken into approximately 30 second increments.  Finally I think it would be nice to be able to change the quality and frame rate.Overall I'm so impressed that I'm ordering an indoor camera and will probably order another outdoor one.

Reviews.Title: Super high quality pictures (especially for a night vision camera)
Reviews.Author: law
Reviews.Content: I know there are many detail reviews about this camera, so I'm not going to repeat everything. If you're looking to buy a security camera and don't want to read those super long (but very helpful) reviews, here are a couple selling points for this camera:1. Easy installation: since it only require one power outlet on the camera side, there is only ONE cat5 cable going from the camera to its adapter and then ONE power cable from the adapter to the outlet. On the router side, there is only ONE cat5 cable going from the adapter to the router and the adapter plugs directly to the wall outlet.2. Easy setup: since it is NOT an IP camera and it does NOT use any of your network IP, thus ZERO networking setup is needed. All you need to do is insert the micro sd card (it's pre-inserted, but if you want a bigger card, just swap it out with the 2GB one), mount the camera, pop in the setup CD and follow the onscreen instruction, plug it into a wall outlet, plug in the other adapter and connect to the router and TA-DA! You can start playing with your camera!3. Very good picture quality: pictures are very clear in day time AND at night. The night time quality is basically the grayscale version of the day time picture. I've done some research on many security cameras and this one definitely have the best night vision quality.4. Record on motion: this camera is not a 24/7 recording camera, it only record the footage if motion is detected.

Reviews.Title: READ UPDATE; also info for Mac users & about Powerline
Reviews.Author: Akamai22
Reviews.Content: UPDATE 2: I wish I had known this before I spent $800.... quote from january 23, 2013 press release from Logitech CEO:"...we have initiated the process to divest our remote controls and digital video security categories, ..... by the end of Calendar Year 2013."See third-quarter press release on the Logitech site.  Bummer.ORIGINAL rating and Update #1:I'm trying to add only new info here; these are great cameras, sensitivity is excellent, software is generally good and the quality level is high. I'm pretty happy.Why 4 stars?  The wall wart is huge (2"+ from wall) and ugly.  Good luck getting your wife to allow this thing except behind furniture.  The outside set-up is even uglier as there's a cord from the wall wart to the 110v plug... it's clumsy, big and highly visible.  As others have noted, the micro-sd card is hard to access, but I'm not certain why you'd want to access it regularly (see below).  And it's much easier to access on the indoor versions than it is on this one.There are trade-offs designing a security camera and Logitech has chosen to use the Powerline standard.... this is a good decision as it avoids a lot of cable stringing, but it's not perfect.  You need to understand the downsides.  First, Powerline may not communicate reliably (see below for fuller discussion of why and what you can do about it).  Secondly - as to the outdoor camera - this thing works great.  BUT you need an outlet within about 15 feet and if you don't have one you're going to need to run an extension cord (ugh) or some special flat ethernet line (the weatherproofing of the camera requires this kind of cable).  IF you do all this, are you then going to have an outdoor security camera plugged into an outdoor outlet?  If so, what keeps someone from walking off with the whole thing?  Of course if you run the line in to an indoor outlet, all well and good, but then the convenience of plug-and-play is defeated.Also, the night vision version of the indoor camera (700n) and this outdoor camera don't work well when set up inside to "look out a window".... the infra red is totally defeated by the window glass.  They work fine "looking through the window" for daylight or lighted areas, but not in the dark.MAC USERS:  Everything you read will tell you that this system requires a PC for initial set-up.  This is no longer true:  as of November, 2012 Logitech has the Alert Commander software for OSX (10.6 or higher) available for download.  Installation was very simple and the two cameras were recognized immediately.  There is a very cool feature which allows you to customize the sensitivity areas of each camera, using up to 16 adjustable rectangles to define which motion will trigger the camera and which motion will be ignored.  Very helpful for avoiding triggering by a bush that is in the corner and gets blown around. I'm still learning all the ins and outs but I'm very happy with the picture quality.There are also free apps for the iPad and the iPhone, for live streaming.  Apparently you have to buy the extra cost subscription if you want to download the recordings to your iDevice.  The software has a couple of bugs but they are minor (I have been unable to turn the  camera LEDs off or the camera audio on).And yes, my system is all Apple (Airport eExtreme, etc) and of course Safari works fine when you want to use a browser to view your cameras.FOR EVERYONE:  this system is based on the Powerline technology which passes a signal over your home's electrical wiring.  This has many advantages in terms of quick set-up as you don't have to run a lot of wires around.  I have had Powerline installed in my house for several years as part of my security system and as a very reliable way to distribute ethernet throughout the house without stringing cable.  But there is a key limitation to Powerline which may explain some of the lower ratings you see here....  This is the case with all Powerline set-ups.  In some cases they communicate just fine, but in others they don't.Here's why:  most homes have a 2-branch electrical system.... one 220 volt line comes into the house.  The 220 volt input is split into two 110 volt circuits called "buses".  Each bus has multiple circuits and circuit breakers.  Powerline system will usually work fine on different circuits as long as they're on the SAME bus.  When the signal has to travel from one bus to the other things get iffy.  The way around this is to install a device in your circuit breaker panel called a signal bridge. This device simply passes the signal from one bus to the other, but it takes up two circuit breaker positions.  INSTALLATION IS NOT FOR AMATEURS.If you  share a panel (in an apartment, for example) this may not be possible.  Note that if you share a panel you potentially share the Powerline signal so think about your security.  Other difficulties may arise if you have electrical sub-panels.  And if your condo building has a 440 volt incoming line.... well, I dunno.You can avoid a bridge by keeping your cameras and the receiver (only one of the latter is needed, for up to 6 cameras) on the same bus.
